title: 110_hr853
content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. The Congress acknowledges the importance of preventive methods in improving population health and reducing medical costs. There is a need for an increase in public health professionals, as there are only around 6,000 board-certified physicians in preventive medicine. Many healthcare costs are spent on avoidable chronic conditions, highlighting the significance of preventive measures. However, the number of preventive medicine residency programs and individuals pursuing this field has decreased in recent years. The number of preventive medicine residency programs and individuals pursuing preventive medicine has significantly decreased in recent years. Preventive medicine physicians are uniquely trained to serve patients and communities, and a strong public health system requires a strong preventive medicine workforce. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. Loan payment assistance of up to $20,000 is available for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. Physicians must submit an application to the Secretary of Health and Human Services to request this payment. A preventive medicine physician who receives board certification between fiscal years 2008 and 2012 can receive up to $20,000 in loan payment assistance. The term "medical education loan" refers to the outstanding principal and interest on a loan for medical school expenses. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is referred to as the "Secretary." Authorization of Appropriations.--Sums may be appropriated for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out this section. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit is 25% of expenses for a qualified program, with a limit of $200 per employee. Eligible employers are those who develop and implement a qualified wellness program. An eligible employer is defined as one who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and keeps accurate records of employee participation. A qualified wellness program is one developed and implemented by the employer. The term 'qualified wellness program' for an eligible employer is a program developed and implemented by the employer, in consultation with a wellness program expert, conducting health risk assessments and offering preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers must offer at least 2 preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force annually, along with counseling sessions and seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, and depression. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers must address various health issues such as physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. Qualified employees must make up at least 50% of the eligible employer's full-time staff. Qualified employees for eligible employers must be full-time employees and qualified participants in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs. Qualified employees for eligible employers must participate in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered through a qualified wellness program and undergo a health risk assessment. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to a wellness program employer credit. The amendments include changes to Section 38(b) and the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. These changes are effective after December 31, 2012. The text introduces a new section, "SEC. 25E. WELLNESS PROGRAM PARTICIPANT CREDIT," as an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. This credit applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The new section "SEC. 25E. WELLNESS PROGRAM PARTICIPANT CREDIT" allows a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who are full-time employees and participants in the employer's wellness program. The new section "SEC. 25E. WELLNESS PROGRAM PARTICIPANT CREDIT" offers a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who participate in the employer's wellness program by engaging in preventive services and health risk assessments. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program during the taxable year, in consultation with an individual experienced in wellness programs to ensure participant privacy. The eligible employer must implement a wellness program that includes health risk assessments, preventive services, and counseling sessions on smoking and obesity. The eligible employer must implement wellness seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health for at least 50% of full-time employees. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program, keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs, and have at least 50% of full-time employees participate. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The section on qualified wellness programs for eligible employers will not apply after December 31, 2012. Effective Date: The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
